story: Distraught mum claims psychic , miles away predicted where sons body wasUS psychic Mary Lawton Johnson contacted Kent Police to tell them where they would find missing Alex whose body was found by a dog walker, Rachel claimedAlex Holland with his mum Rachel Image: Triangle NewsByJosie O’BrienGraeme Murray:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA distraught mum has revealed how a psychic , miles away told her where her missing son’s body would be found. Alex Holland’s body was tragically found face down in water by a dog walker on February . His mum Rachel last saw him on the night of November  when he stepped outside their front door to have a cigarette.And she claims US psychic Mary Lawton Johnson contacted both her and Kent Police to tell them where they would find missing Alex, .The renowned medium also says she is convinced Alex was murdered - and that police should do more to investigate. Mary, who lives in Florida and has never been to the Hollands’ hometown in Kent, saw visions of Alex face down in a pool of water. She says she sent  emails to the police and Alex’s family with maps highlighting areas of water which should be searched. Despite pressure from both women, police did not search those areas. Guidelines published by the College of Policing in  advise that information from psychics should not be dismissed. According to mum Rachel, Alex was found in one of Mary’s highlighted areas wearing one shoe and his death still remains a mystery. The other open-toed and backless shoe was recovered ft from where his hire car was found.His phone was still in the car, but no suicide note had been left. Despite putting pressure on the police to find them, Rachel says she still doesnapost know where his wallet or car keys are. Alex’s body was found approximately . miles away from their family home in Deal, Kent. Rachel, , suspects that her son was murdered and his body disposed of in the water - a suspicion Mary supports. The psychic believes three people were involved in Alex’s death. A post mortem examination has recorded the cause of death as aposunexplainedapos. Rachel said: “I believe my son was murdered. “Right now, I can’t prove that but I do because too many things don’t add up. “I just want the truth. “Last time I saw him, he popped his head round my bedroom door and told me and his dad he was going to have a cigarette, shower and then go to bed. “He asked his dad to wake him up in the morning for work. “But I got up an hour later to go to the toilet and realised he wasn’t in, so I thought he must have just gone out. “I was phoning his mobile the next day, and come tea time I was worried. “I thought ‘I need to know where he is’ and called the police to report him missing.” Alex was living back home with his parents after separating from his we before he went missing. Police and search parties went looking for him  hours after he was last seen. His body wasn’t found for another  days.  Rachel is certain her son didn’t commit suicide. She added: “I know what it’s like to hit a point so low that you’re at that stage - but my son wasn’t like that. “And he would have never left his two girls - he loved them. “He was such a loving dad. “He was a loving son too, he was a good son. “He’d phone us every day to check in on us.” Psychic Mary made contact with Alex’s family in the weeks after he went missing. She told Rachel that she had driven past a very angry man on the side of the road near her home in Florida. She quickly realised that man was a vision of Alex. Mary was quite scared by how angry Alex was and told his family it was because he had been jumped and killed the night he went missing. Rachel added: “I’ve said that to the police since day one. “I believe he was dragged out of his car and taken in another vehicle and killed. “Police wouldn’t believe me - they wouldn’t listen to a single word I said.”Alex’s family raised awareness of his disappearance with emotional appeals and a dedicated Facebook page.After months of no leads, his body was recovered from water in Hacklinge, Kent. Officials have stipulated to his family that he is likely to have been there the whole time - meaning Mary’s predictions were right all along. Mary says she has sent descriptions of three suspects to officers but police continue to treat Alex’s death as non-suspicious. Toxicology reports are not expected for at least another  weeks. Kent Police said officers have made extensive enquiries following the death of Alex Holland from Deal who had been reported missing on Sunday  November  and whose body was discovered on Thursday  February  near Hacklinge in Kent. A report is being prepared for the coroner who will hold an inquest to determine the cause of death. Detective Inspector Louise Murphy of Kent Police said: A number of enquiries have been carried out into the circumstances of the death, including reviewing CCTV footage and examining mobile phone data and, based on the available information, there is nothing so far to suggest the death is suspicious. A post-mortem has been completed and we are treating the death as unexplained at this stage, pending further toxicology results. All of the evidence gathered will be submitted to the coroner for consideration. Updates have been provided to the family of the deceased where appropriate and we will continue to relay any concerns or questions they may have to the coroner. We appreciate how dficult this is for Alex’s family and friends and our thoughts remain with them. title: eight year old alopecia defies
story: Eight-year-old with alopecia defies bullies and ditches wig to embrace unique lookAn eight-year-old girl was taunted by bullies after alopecia caused her to lose her hair, but shes refused to let this knock her confidence, ditching her wig and embracing her unique lookNiamh decided that wigs were not for her Image: Caters NewsByJulia BanimAudience WriterKaty-Rose Meaney:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments Niamh Lewis, now eight, began experiencing hair loss when she was just three years old, with alopecia eventually leaving her without hair, eyebrows, or eyelashes. Sadly, this led to taunts from school bullies and stares from strangers on the street.However, despite cruel comments, determined Niamh, of Glyncorrwg, South Wales, refuses to feel downhearted, choosing instead to embrace looking dferent. Her mum, Amy, couldnapost be prouder with how Niamh has dealt with nasty remarks from bullies, or comments from those who stop her in the street, describing her as confident in her own skin and an inspiration to us all. Brave Niamh has now decided to stop wearing her wig out and about and has also chosen to sign up to a number of modelling agencies, all while supporting other women and girls with the condition. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here.Alopecia, which can be a temporary or permanent condition, happens when an overactive immune system attacks a personaposs hair follicles due to genetic factors, hormonal changes, or medical conditions.Itaposs unclear whether or not Niamhaposs hair will ever grow back. She began losing patches of hair when she was three, despite having been born with a full head of hair and having had long hair as a toddler, and experiencing more rapid hair loss when she turned five. Amy, , said: It started as three patches, Niamh didnapost notice and it grew back. We tried dferent styles to cover the patches, but the hair was becoming very fine and tangly. When Niamh turned five in December, it became more noticeable and by the summer holidays it was all gone. Niamh said to me,my body needs hair it will grow it. aposMum, letaposs just go with the flowapos, so now we only speak positively about hair loss. The terms apossuffering withapos or a apossurvivor ofapos are not words we use. However, the mum-of-one does admit that she struggles with the loss of Niamhaposs hair, continuing: As her mother, I grieved for her hair and found the loss hard to deal with. I worried about her future, especially as a female with no hair. I always worry how she will be treated by others who donapost understand.  When Niamh first began losing her hair, she was donated a wig from The Little Princess Trust. However, she came to realise that this wasnapost the right option for her. Events manager Amy said: I did so much reading and so much research. I tried a wig when she was five, but she doesnapost want it anymore. It was too much for her tiny little features and it was would get hot and itchy. She loves to swim and hang upside down outside like a typical child and the wig got in the way so she said no. We tried head scarfs and sometimes she wears accessories for fun, but normally she prefers to not wear anything. We focus on all the positives. Face paint can go everywhere and she is the first to get ready for swimming, and of course, we never had to brush out painful tangles. Unfortunately, Niamhaposs family has had to contend with adults staring at her on a daily basis, with many assuming her hair loss is down to illness. According to Amy: Kids would call her baldy and some of the girls wouldnapost play with her. Wherever we go people stare. They assume she has cancer or a terminal illness Now she is older she can explain to people she isnapost poorly and I try and reassure people she is ok and her hair loss is not cancer-related, but Iaposve had strangers hug me and cry and give her money or sweets. Because we believe you deserve it. #mirrormorehopefulFollow on Twitter @mirrormorehope And follow Mirror More Hopeful on Facebook The mum and daughter have decided against going with medical intervention to stop the hair loss, with Amy explaining that, although there are steroid injections available, she felt it was a lot to put Niamh through.Amy, who now home educates Niamh, continued: You can also buy steroid-based creams but decided against that as it may irate her eczema. Itaposs about weighing up whataposs best for each person.Niamh has recently signed up to a number of modelling agencies, with the aim of embracing her unique look. According to Amy, who hopes to see those with alopecia better represented in mainstream modelling, this is something Niamh really enjoys, with the little girl having never lost her confidence in front the camera.The youngster has also set up an Instagram page in order to connect with other people living with the condition, while she and Niamh and her mother are also involved with Alopecia UK.Amy, who hopes to establish the first support group in Wales, added: Niamh started to question what she might look like as she gets older so we follow women and children all over the world with Alopecia and itaposs great to have that support.Do you have a story of courage to share  We pay for stories. title: ex cop cancels week watching
story: Ex-cop cancels week off watching Netflix to help refugees escaping UkrainePaul Stratton had booked a week off work and was planning some down time "watching Netflix and eating Pringles", but after seeing the scenes of desperation of those fleeing from Russias invasion - he made a dramatic change of planPaul and his brother will stay in Poland, doing all they can to help the refugees arriving in their thousands, before ing to Liverpool on Sunday Image: Liverpool Post And EchoByLiam ThorpLiverpool Echo political editorRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsA man cancelled his week off watching Netflix and eating Pringles to help desperate refugees fleeing a warzone. Paul Stratton was planning some downtime from his job at Liverpool Council, but after seeing devastating scenes of innocent Ukrainians being driven out of their homes by Russiaaposs invasion - he made a dramatic change of plan. The former cop and his brother made the -mile trip to to Przemyśl, in Poland, where Ukrainian refugees are arriving in their thousands - many of them without a penny or possession to their name. The pair will stay until Sunday before heading home, the Liverpool Echo reports.Though the brothers donapost speak the language, they are getting along with a Polish phrasebook and a network of former police and army colleagues. They recently met the Mayor of Przemyśl and asked what they could do to help. He told them to buy chocolate for the children as itaposs the only thing that makes them smile.So the brothers emptied out the local supermarket, buying £ of chocolate bars, which went in two minutes. Paul said: People are desperate to get something for their kids. And the children were so polite, saying thank you. It’s not dawned on them what’s happened.”  While many people are helping, more support is needed for the volume of people arriving from Ukraine.The reception centre in Przemyśl – which has been hastily set up in a nearby shopping centre – can only process , people a day. Paul said: We’ve given them four more laptops, doubling what they had to start with. And we’re desperately trying to get them faster broadband. Local boy scouts, who are brilliant on the computers, are helping to register people, though it’s dficult as they don’t speak Ukrainian.”  He added: There aren’t enough staff here. There’s no Red Cross or local government. The Polish people are wonderful, beyond heroes – they’re setting an example to the world of what it is to show humanity. The city streets are empty, as everyone is volunteering. But we desperately need more drivers, translators – and money.” The city’s railway station is packed with children, sitting on the floor, waiting. It’s too cold to go outside and play, as temperatures plummet to minus . Paul added: “I started out with sympathy, but it’s now turned into anger. I want to bring them all home to keep them safe.” Liverpool City Council Chief Executive, Tony Reeves, said: “I think it’s incredible what Paul has done to help in this situation, he really is to be commended for his selflessness, kindness and compassion. It is a wonderful example of public service and we should all be very proud of him.” Paul is planning toto Poland to volunteer for another week, later this month. story: Gran whos never been north of the Thames stunned by £ Newcastle tunnel fineJulie Barnett, from Kent, was confused when she received an Unpaid Toll Charge Noticefrom tunnel operator TT in relation to a journey through the Tyne Tunnel which she never madeJulie Barnett, from Kent, was confused when she received a fine for travelling through the Tyne Tunnel Image: BBCByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Mar  from tunnel operator TT in relation to a journey through the Tyne Tunnel which she never made" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Woman-stunned-by-£-tunnel-fine-when-shes-never-even-been-near-it.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top" from tunnel operator TT in relation to a journey through the Tyne Tunnel which she never made" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Woman-stunned-by-£-tunnel-fine-when-shes-never-even-been-near-it.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top" from tunnel operator TT in relation to a journey through the Tyne Tunnel which she never made" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Woman-stunned-by-£-tunnel-fine-when-shes-never-even-been-near-it.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"|comments A granny who has never been north of the River Thames was left baffled after being hit with a £ from a tunnel in Newcastle. The crossing has irked countless drivers since it made the switch to a new cashless system in November.But Julie Barnett, from Kent, has now had a run-in with the new toll payment scheme despite never even passing through the Tyne Tunnel.Julie, who said she had to Google the underpassaposs location, said she was confused after receiving an Unpaid Toll Charge Noticefrom tunnel operator TT in December, reports Chronicle Live.The -year-old - who lives on the Isle of Sheppey - claims to have never been north of the Thames and has never visited the North East.  She believes that the automatic cameras installed to capture the registration numbers of vehicles driving through the tunnel misread one plate, seemingly mistaking a U for an O, and wrongly recorded her car as having made a journey. After immediately writing to TT to inform them of the error, Mrs Barnett received a letter of apology acknowledging the error on December . But she then received a final payment reminder notice in January, after which she wrote to TT again and got no reply, and has now been sent an enforcement notice from debt collectors telling her that she owes a whopping £.. Now that the toll plazas have been removed from the north side of the tunnel, car drivers must pay their £. crossing fee by midnight the next day – either online, with a pre-paid account, over the phone, or in shops with PayPoint counters. Those who fail to do so face a £ penalty that will increase to £, plus the original toll charge and extra administrative costs,not settled within  days. After Mrs Barnett got in touch with the Local Democracy Reporting Service, TT has said it will cancel her fine and blamed the problem on there being two UTCNs associated with her car rather than just the one that she had successfully appealed in December.The retiree, who has two children and one grandson, said the experience had been “very stressful” and complained that TT “make it easy to pay, but not easy to contact them”. She added: “I wrote to them in December to say this was not my car – the one in the picture has a dferent shape number plate to mine andyou look closely you can see it is a dferent registration. “They apologised to me, but then I got a final payment reminder notice in January. I wrote to TT again but did not get a response this time. “I thought it had been dealt with and they had forgotten about me, but then the next thing you know I am getting an enforcement notice telling me that I owe a lot of money – £.. “It has all been quite distressing.” A TT spokesperson said on Tuesday that, after investigating Mrs Barnett’s case, they found two UTCNs linked to her car – one that was cancelled in December and another that had been escalated to enforcement levels. They added: “However, since she has now brought this to our attention, we are happy to confirm that we have cancelled the second UTCN. “TT will always try to work with our customers to resolve any issues like this.” Almost , people have backed a petition slamming “simply unacceptable” errors with the new payment system and a surge in motorists being hit with heavy fines, while a councillor last week labelled the switch to the ‘Tyne Pass’ project an “absolute disaster”. Latest figures show that just .% of drivers going through the tunnel are getting fined for non-payment of tolls, but that still amounts to around , penalties being issued per month. story: Hero boy, , saves mum by calling ambulance after she fell ill at home Little Benji called  as his mum Becky Garrett drted in and out of consciousness at their home in Drumchapel, Glasgow and gave her his teddy for companyThe six-year-old, who wants to be a firefighter when hes older, was rewarded with a tour of the fire station and bravery certicate Image: Scottish Ambulance ServiceByNaina BhardwajTrainee ReporterJoe Smith:,  Mar |comments A six-year-old has been called a superstar after he took it upon himself to call an ambulance for his mum when she took unwell at their home. Benji, of Drumchapel, Glasgow, called  as his mum, Becky Garrett, drted in and out of consciousness before giving her one of his teddies so she wasn’t lonely. Becky explained that she doesnapost remember much of the day except for walking up and feeling horrendous, the Daily Record reports.She continued: “I was unable to take Benji to school and as the day went on, I gradually began to feel worse and worse. Due to having such a high temperature, I really wasn’t with it at all and from my understanding I was drting in and out of consciousness.”  Noticing how unwell his mum was feeling, Benji decided to call the emergency services.John McCue was one of three Scottish Ambulance Servicestaff members who attended the scene on Tuesday, January .He said: “When we arrived, Becky was lying on the sofa. She was responsive to voice, pale and said she was cold. When we checked her temperature, it was very high - more than  degrees. It was decided that she required further assessment at hospital. We ensured that Benji was with a responsible adult whom he knew before leaving for Queen Elizabeth University Hospital.”  John added: “Benji was his mum’s hero that day, realising that she needed help and being brave enough to call  and ask for an ambulance. When we were leaving for the hospital, Benji gave his mum one of his favourite teddies so she wouldnapost be lonely.”Benji visited the SAS base in Maryhill, Glasgow which is co-located with the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service, on Saturday, March .The six-year-old, who wants to be a firefighter when heaposs older, was rewarded with a tour of the fire station and bravery certicate. Becky said: “As you can imagine, this must have been so scary for a six-year-old to deal with but he did it and thanks to him I got the help I needed and have made a full recovery.” “I can’t even begin to describe how immensely proud I am of Benji - he really is my superstar. Although I have tried my best to make him aware of the importance of knowing what to do in an emergency, I am just so proud that he actually remembered and stayed calm enough to not only dial  but also had the initiative to phone a family friend to let them know I was unwell too.” Following the incident, Becky is now encouraging other parents to teach their kids how to call . She concluded: “If there’s one message you can take from this, it is to please try your best to make them aware of the emergency services number and when is appropriate to use it - it really can make all the dference. Who knows what wouldaposve happened had Benji not done that for me - he really is my hero.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Daily RecordSuperstarHospitalsRoyal FamilyEmergencyMedicine" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Kate Middletons university nickname caught Williams attention and led to breakfast inviteRoyal author Katie Nicholl has revealed the nickname Kate Middletons peers gave her during university Freshers Week before Prince William arrivedKate Middleton and Prince William Image: Clarence House via GettyImagesByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Mar |commentsUniversity is a time to study, but itaposs also a time to have fun with friends - and the Duchess of Cambridge did just that. Kate enrolled at the University of St Andrews in Fe, Scotland, where she studied the history of art.And while she has never been a big drinker, she threw herself into Freshersapos Week - a university tradition of welcoming new students with a week of nights out and partying - and earned herself an impressive nickname. Royal author Katie Nicholl shares stories of Kateaposs youth in her book Kate: The Future Queen, during which she claims Kate had hectic week of partying, meeting her aposuniversity parents - older pupils who were in charge of looking after freshers - finding her way around town and settling into her residence hall. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm.Click here to sign up.Kate soon found her way around and was often seen relaxing in the common room, curled up in an armchair, a cup of tea in hand, either reading newspaper articles her father rather touchingly mailed to her or getting to know her fellow hall mates. Prince William also studied at the university and arrived the following week.He moved into the flat above Kateaposs and it didnapost take him long to notice the stunning brunette - probably because of the nickname she was given by her peers. According to Katie, she had been dubbed aposBeautul Kateapos by the end of Freshersapos Week.She writes: She was initially more reserved than many of the other young women, but her natural beauty was apparent. Tanned from a recent holiday in Barbados with her parents, fit from regular early morning run or swim, and dressed in her comfortable Hennes jeans, fitted sweater and signature cowboy boots, she radiated an outer freshness and an inner confidence. news uk-news kate-not-forget-how-meghan-"Meghan Markle reveals Kate made HER cry before the royal weddingByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Mar |commentsThe Duchess of Cambridge will not forget how she was treated by sister-in-law Meghan Markle following her bombshell Oprah Winfrey interview, a royal expert has said. A year has now passed since Meghan and husband Prince Harry sat down with the chat show host for an explosive interview, where they made a number of claims about their time as working members of the Royal Family. Before the interview, there were numerous reports that Meghan made Kate cry during a bridesmaid dress fitting in the lead up to her wedding to Harry.But during her one-on-one with Oprah, Meghan claimed it was actually Kate that made her cry. Meghan said she has now forgiven Kate, adding that sheaposs a good person and that Kate sent her flowers to apologise for the incident - although gave no details on what sparked the incident, and it is still not known for certain.Now, it is thought that Harry and Meghan could come to the UK in the summer to take part in celebrations for the Queenaposs Platinum Jubilee. And according to royal author and editor-in-chief of Majesty Magazine, Ingrid Seward, the two women will be cordial - although Kate may never forget how she was treated. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up .She told the Mirror: The Duchess of Cambridge will be cordial to Meghan. She will be sure to be photographed kissing or hugging her. She has to - that is part of her job. Her private feelings have to remain just that. Kate will not forget however how Meghan treated her. But she knows there is no point in prolonging a feud that has the opportunity of being repaired. The Platinum Jubilee is just that chance. If necessary, Kate will also try to be the peacemaker between William and his brother Harry.  Being royal is all about appearances, not private feelings. It always has been throughout history. It is what the Queen has spent  years perfecting and she expects her family to do the same.Not only was Kate mentioned in the Oprah interview, Harry and Meghan also made a number of claims about the wider Royal Family. They alleged that there had been conversations about how dark son Archieaposs skin would be, while Meghan shared that she had suffered from suicidal thoughts and claimed that she was denied help for her struggle. And Ingrid, the author of Prince Philip Revealed: A Man of his Century, believes although the interview will never be forgotten by the likes of the Queen and Prince Charles, they know there is nothing to gain from shutting them out of the Jubilee celebrations.She explained: When Princess Diana criticised her husband and his family in her Panorama interview, it was the end of not only her marriage but any kind of honest relationship with her husband’s family. I suspect that the Duke and Duchess of Sussex are experiencing a similar situation.  Their explosive interview with Oprah will never be forgotten. Neither will the words from the Buckingham Palace statement on behalf of the Queen ‘Recollections may y.’ Harry’s public criticism of his father. His insistence on prioritising his own mental health over everything. His persistence on declaring the royal world into which he was born is ‘toxic’ does not endear the Duke and Duchess of Sussex to the Royal Family. But the Queen knows better than anyone there is nothing to be gained by open hostility. She is always prepared to forgivenot forget. Prince Charles is the same. They have little choicethey ever want to see Harry again, which of course they do. Harry needs Meghan to be included and she will be, whatever the family may feel about her privately. Both the Queen and Charles want to see their grandchildren and great-grandchildren. There is nothing to be gained by shutting them out and of course, they will be invited to the Platinum Jubilee celebrations. They may be guests not actual participants. But they will be there. title: parish priest sacked after conducting
story: Parish priest sacked after conducting full immersion baptism in his boxer shortsReverend Clive Roger Evans, , of Hereford, touched a womans bottom and stripped down to his boxer shorts to carry out the baptism, a disciplinary tribunal foundRevd Clive Roger Evans, , conducted the baptism semi-naked, a hearing found Image: @StPetersChurchBromyard FacebookByMatthew CooperCricket WriterLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar A married priest has been sacked after touching two people without their consent and holding a full immersion baptism wearing nothing but his underwear.Revd Clive Roger Evans, , stripped down to his boxer shorts and touched the bottoms of a woman and a girl, according to a disciplinary tribunal by the Diocese of Hereford.The hearing found that the parish priest had engaged in conduct unbecoming or inappropriate to the office and work of a clerk in Holy Orders.In a -page ruling, the five-member tribunal accepted Revd Evansapos evidence that he was initially reluctant to perform the baptism several years ago as he was due to go away on holiday with his we.The , which heard evidence in December last year, said: Revd Evans gave evidence that he finished his breakfast and did his packing before leaving.  The  finds that there was ample opportunity at this stage for Revd Evans to give thought to including a change of clothing for conducting the baptism, which he knew at this stage was to be a full immersion using the bath. The  does accept that Revd Evans felt there was an urgency to the request and that this led him to take the unusual step of acquiescing to it and stopping off en route to his holiday to perform the baptism. We do not, however, accept that the degree of urgency was extreme or that it was perceived as such. The  said that the clergyman had ample time to consider what it would be appropriate to wear and that underwear is intimate apparel. It is qualitatively dferent to, and has dferent associations from, other forms of clothing or even of swimwear, it added. As such there is a loss of dignity by stripping down to underwear in the circumstances in which it occurred which is inherently inappropriate and unbecoming. There was no extreme urgency which might conceivably be imagined to justy a state of semi-nakedness and public display of underwear. In its sanction of the priest, who was the Vicar of Bromyard and Stoke Lacy in Herefordshire, the  removed him from office and prohibited him from exercising any of the s of his orders for a period of six months. It also imposed an injunction that he should complete training courses relating to safeguarding, appropriate working and pastoral boundaries prior to any recommencement of ministry. The tribunal also granted anonymity to those concerned in the allegations. title: pregnant nursery worker wins 25000
story: Pregnant nursery worker wins £, after boss askedkeeping baby was good ideaDarci Toppings bosses at her new job at Stepping Stones Nursery in Lancashire quizzed her about the babys father and asked herkeeping the baby was a good ideaDarci Topping with one-year-old son Stanley, she won the money after challenging Stepping Stones Nursery at an employment tribunal Image: LancsLiveByJoe Smith:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA nursery worker who told her bosses she was pregnant a week after starting her new job has won £, after she was askedkeeping the baby was a ‘good idea’. Darci Topping, a qualied nursery nurse, started work at Stepping Stones Nursery in the Lancashire village of Hoddlesden in February . A week later she told her line manager she was pregnant.The  year old - who was on minimum wage - was then subjected to aposnegative inferencesapos about her pregnancy by her managers, was quizzed about the babyaposs father and about her intention to go through with the birth. She was also apospressuredapos into reducing her hours as the Covid- pandemic hit and then made redundant out of the blue, the employment tribunal heard.But bosses at Stepping Stones Nursery had aposdressed upapos her sacking with a sham process because she was pregnant, the tribunal ruled.  Miss Topping, who now has one-year-old son Stanley, has been awarded £, after she successfully sued the nursery at an employment tribunal for pregnancy discrimination and unfair dismissal. The tribunal in Manchester was told qualied nursery nurse started at the nursery near Blackburn on February  in  on a -hour-a-week contract. A week later, on March , Miss Topping, from Blackburn, announced to her line manager Zara Costello that she was pregnant with her first child. A tribunal report said: A few days later, in the course of a discussion about her pregnancy, Ms Costello told her that Julie Mercer, the owner of the nursery, would aposcome round to itapos, and she mentioned the fact that Miss Topping was on probation. Other comments were made, including questions about whether Miss Topping was, in fact, going to keep the baby and whether that would be a good idea, and reference was made to Miss Toppingaposs partner or father of the baby at the time. As the Covid- pandemic hit days later and Stepping Stones Nursery became worried about finances, Miss Topping was told her hours needed to be cut to  a week and wasnapost given any consultation. She was forced to sign a aposhastilyapos typed up document agreeing to cutting her hours - but was the only worker to have her shts formally cut. Miss Topping was aposanxiousapos over the pandemicaposs impact on her health and whether or not she would have a job, the tribunal heard. She was placed on sick leave initially but then placed on furlough as well as other members of staff. However, she was the only one to receive  per cent of wages for  hours a week, rather than . Despite things being aposstableapos at the nursery, she was made redundant out of the blue while on furlough, leaving her aposvery upsetapos. Ms Costello even suggested she aposmight be better off on benefitsapos during the telephone call. The report said: By April , , the numbers of children attending the nursery each day had stabilised. Miss Topping was by then on furlough with other employees at no cost to the nursery. What happened then was that Ms Costello simply rang up Miss Topping and announced her dismissal as .From the evidence presented, the Tribunal considered that the nursery dressed up her dismissal by constructing a redundancy process which either never took place or took place after the nursery made its decision to dismiss her. Miss Topping launched legal action, claiming the nursery aposhad a problem with pregnant employeesapos. Employment Judge Marion Batten said: The Tribunal concluded that the decision to make her redundant was a decision targeted at her alone - she was pregnant and in light of the paucity of the evidence, it was apparent that was the only dference. There was no other credible explanation offered by the nursery. The tribunal had no hesitation in concluding that her dismissal was related to her pregnancy. Only she was dismissed. She was the only employee who was pregnant, and in the context of her treatment by the nursery since she told them, at the beginning of March , that she was pregnant. Following the case, Miss Stanley said she is aposglad to have won the tribunalapos. She added: It was very tough for me being made redundant at such a vulnerable point in my le while expecting my first baby which I wanted to be excited about. I do feel that I have got justice and I am relieved that the case is finally over. title: private jet impounded uk airport
story: Private jet impounded at UK airport over fears it dodged Russian loopholesThe Bombardier Global  arrived at Farnborough airport in Hampshire on March  from New Jersey and was due to fly to Dubai yesterday - Transport Secretary Grant Shapps today said he temporarily banned it from carrying passengers and grounded itThis private jet at Farnborough airport in Hampshire has been impounded Image: Humphrey NemarByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments A private jet has been impounded over fears its dodged Russian loopholes. The Bombardier Global  arrived at Farnborough airport in Hampshire on March  from New Jersey and was due to fly to Dubai yesterday.Transport Secretary Grant Shapps today said he temporarily banned it from carrying passengers and grounded it in order to investigate claims that it could be linked to Russian oligarch Eugene Shvidler.The billionaire oil tycoon is a pal of Roman Abramovich, the owner of Cha football club who is now selling the club after the UK first imposed sanctions against the oligarchs. Want all the latest news and analysis from Ukraine to our World News Bulletin here  A government source has said Mr Shvidler is free to continue his journey by other means, Sky News reports. However, a revoked foreign carrier permit and restriction of flying order will mean the plan will remain grounded in the UK until Attorney General Suella Braverman and the National Crime Agency carry out their investigation. The Transport Secretary has ordered the Civil Aviation Authorityto terminate the registration of planes owned by sanctioned Russian oligarchs. Follow all todayaposs latest updates on the conflict with our live blog Mr Shapps told BBC Breakfast today Russian airlines and private jets had already been banned from the UK.He said: However there were potential loopholes and I also wanted to make the issue a criminal one, so last night I also signed a law which closes off some of those loopholes to do with trying to work out the ownership of some of these aircraft. There is one such aircraft on the ground at Farnborough that I have essentially impounded whilst we carry out further investigations, for the last few days.  Itaposs very important that we have the laws available to enable that to happen. The jet is registered to Luxembourg-based firm Global Jet Luxembourg, but who actually owns the private planes is often hard to find because it normally involves third parties. Today, the government brought in new rules making it illegal for any plane chartered or owned by Russians to enter UK airspace. Mr Shapps claimed Britain is the first country in the world to do so. All Russian commercial flights have been banned from UK airspace since the Ukrainian invasion began.It comes as Vladimir Putin could “flatten Ukraine ” despite his war ultimately ending in failure, Western officials fear. Officials also warned they have good reason to be concerned about the possible use of non conventional weapons - such as chemical weapons - by Russia.An official said: “We’re seeing some of the disinformation come out of Moscow about non-conventional weapons.  We saw this in Syria, the Russians starting that talk when they or their proxies were about to use those weapons there.” They added: “It’s a serious concern for us”. An official said: “I think it will end badly for Putin. That doesn’t mean it ends well for Ukraine at all. “This could end very badly for both. And saying it ends badly for Putin does not mean the Russians not getting into Kyiv, or doing fantastic damage to it with appalling humanitarian costs along the way.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON BBCCivil Aviation AuthorityRoman AbramovichGrant ShappsVladimir PutinHospitalsPrivate jetsCrimeBillionaires" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news six-times-queen-sent-secret-"Queen praises work of Charles and William in COP speechByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Mar |comments They say actions speak louder than words - and it seems this is very much the case for the Queen. She rarely talks about her inner most thoughts and feelings, but sometimes instead uses her clothes, jewellery or even her surroundings to send what some believe are secret messages.Just this week while meeting with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau at Windsor Castle, and royal watchers were quick to point out the beautul blue and yellow flowers in the background.Of course yellow and blue are the colours of the Ukrainian flag and it was seen as a tribute to the people of the country amid the Russian invasion. So what other secret messages has she seemingly sent in recent years  Here we take a look... Ukraine flowers  The most recent subtle message was of course the the blue and yellow flowers on display at Windsor Castle during an audience with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.Mr Trudeau was in London earlier this week for talks on the war in Ukraine with Boris Johnson and Dutch counterpart Mark Rutte.Sources said that the small gesture of the flowers was a deliberate sign of the Queenaposs solidarity with the people of Ukraine.Later, at a press conference with Mr Johnson and Mr Rutte, Mr Trudeau confirmed he talked to Her Majesty about Ukraine. He explained: I can tell you in my conversation with her this morning she was as insightful and perspicacious as ever, very interested in whataposs going on. Brexit hat Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. In , the Queen attended the State Opening of Parliament wearing a vibrant blue hat that featured yellow flowers.At that time the debate surrounding the aftermath of the Brexit vote was raging in the UK and in her speech, which is written by the government, she outlined how the country was preparing to exit the EU. However, many people on social media couldnapost help but notice that her hat very much resembled that of the European Union flag.In , in her book The Other Side of the Coin: The Queen, the Dresser and the Wardrobe, the Queen dresser Angela Kelly insisted it never occurred to her the hat resembled the flag. Anniversary brooch During last yearaposs deeply personal Christmas message, the Queen paid an extraordinary tribute to her late beloved husband Prince Philip. Pinned to her dress was a stunning sapphire chrysanthemum brooch that royal fans pointed out she wore on many happy times with the Duke of Edinburgh - believing it was a tribute to him. Among the times she wore the brooch was on her honeymoon in  and to mark her rd wedding anniversary in . Red boxes Just last month, an image of a beaming Queen was released to mark Her Majestyaposs Platinum Jubilee year. It shows her at Sandringham going through papers from her red box, which she is sent everyday from the Government. And according to former royal butler Grant Harrold, it was signicant the boxes were included in the snap. He said on Tik Tok: People keep asking me do I think the Queen is going to continue with her work  Well in this photograph you see one of her official government boxes and of course this is the Queen doing her day to day work. I think this shows all of us that even though sheaposs now coming into her th year, sheaposs been on the throne  years, she is very much going to continue being a monarch. Lockdown message brooch  One of the most important address the Queen has given to the country in the past two years came in April .In it, she spoke of the unprecedented nature of the Covid pandemic being fought around the globe and promised we will meet again despite lockdown.For the speech, the Queen wore a beautul turquoise and diamond brooch that once belonged to her grandmother Queen Mary. It was later pointed out that stone is said to be one that promotes healing and love as well as enhances the powers of leadership. Cop outfit Last November, a bout of ill health meant the Queen had to pull out of attending the Cop climate change summit in Glasgow.However, she recorded a rousing video message where she urged world leaders to help protect the planet.For the speech, she wore a green dress, which is of course the colour of being environmentally friendly. She paired it with a rare a diamond and ruby butterfly which was gted to her upon her engagement to Prince Philip. And many believed it was her subtle way of paying tribute to her late husband, who had been heavily involved in environmental matters. title: uk weather forecast 70mph gales
story: UK weather forecast: mph gales, rain and snow to batter the country from todayA yellow warning has been issued by the Met Office as severe gales are predicted that could reach mph along with wind and snow in midweek for the west while it will be milder in the eastThe UK is set to be blasted by gale force winds Image: Colin Lane Liverpool EchoByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments Brits are being warned of severe mph gales and snow for midweek with a mixture of frost and milder weather in an east-west ide.A low pressure front is sweeping in from the Atlantic bringing strong winds, rain and snow to the west of the country through Wednesday and Thursday while the weather will be brighter in the east and the mercury could rise to highs in the mid teens.The Met Office has issued a weather warning for north west Scotland that will run from am until am on Wednesday.It states: “Severe gales may lead to some disruption on Wednesday morning.” Adding people can expect: “Some delays to road, rail, air and ferry transport are likely. Probably some bus services affected with some journeys taking longer.”  Met Office forecaster Clare Nasir said: “Windy on Wednesday with gales towards the north west and also some heavy rain. Dry skies towards the south and the east.” She continued: “We could see severe gales for a time as the strongest winds extend to the far north of Scotland. We could even see some damaging gust across the east side of Northern Ireland again through the morning associated with that rain band with some heavy bursts.” At the same time it is likely to be a dry start to Wednesday across England and Wales before the rain moves in.  “This rain gradually pushes in and again these winds will be incredibly strong particularly through the north channel, said Ms Nasir. Now the cloud will come and go across England and Wales as well as eastern Scotland but some brighter weather, even some sunshine across eastern counties during the day. At the same time rain will slowly clip western part of Wales as well as the West Country, hanging onto that wet weather for Northern Ireland as well as western Scotland and an undercut of cold air will allow snow to fall especially above m. So west will see the strongest winds, outbreaks of rain, east temperatures will be C to C.  Maps from WXCharts shows that a couple of centimetres of snow can be expected in Scotland overnight going into Thursday.And BBC weather forecaster Nick Miller has also predicted snow that will come along with the gales.“Some severe gales, gusts up to -mph, could be disruptive before they ease,” he said.  This weather system weakens moving east over night and into Thursday on its back edge it will have some some snow towards the Highlands and southern uplands for a time. In the clear spells in north west Scotland and Northern Ireland as Thursday begins there will be a frost here and especially in Northern Ireland there is a risk of seeing some fog. UK forecast for the next  days Wet and windy in the west, drier in the east. Today: Low cloud across central, southern and eastern England breaking to allow sunny spells. A band of rain, heavy at times, will move slowly eastwards across Northern Ireland, Scotland, Wales and then western England. Severe gales across western Scotland at first. Tonight: Outbreaks of rain across some northern and western parts, though rain turning lighter and patchier. Dry with clear spells in the southeast, and also the far northwest where turning frosty. Thursday: Cloudy across many parts with patchy light rain and drizzle edging slowly eastwards. Brighter across some western areas. Turning windy in the west later. Outlook for Friday to Sunday: Rather unsettled with outbreaks of rain at times for most parts of the UK, heaviest and most prolonged in western areas. Strong winds at times, especially along western coastal areas. The £, three-bed homeaposs listing boasts that it must be seen and despite its plain-looking exterior, a browse through the photos inside soon reveals why. Photos showcase the owneraposs apparent disdain for neutrals or anything ordinary with flamboyant art, neon and clashing colours, gaudy textured gold walls, VIP toilet seats and even a giant face protruding through one wall.In the Rightmove property in Edmonton, Greater London, pictures show a bold colour palette of pillarbox red and lime green while another has multi-coloured marble-effect walls.In other areas a gold textured corridor can be seen.  The Rightmove listing, marketed by  Key Properties, advises that early viewings are aposhighly recommendedapos and highlights the propertyaposs high ceilings bathroom jacuzzi and gardens. The home was previously on the market in , before the vendor decided against selling.Online house hunters were stunned by the ostentatious interior design, claiming that some choices were apos migraine inducingapos - even likening the decor to something by world-famous graphic artist M.C. Alisa Jane wrote: You could just move in there, no decorating required, to which Sarah replied: Just the pictures are migraine inducing...One Twitter user wrote: All that in a modest terrace.Another commenter wrote: Itaposs the texture aposeffectapos walls I canapost square. The colour scheme inside defies the propertyaposs aposordinaryapos exterior and the decor is sure to ide opinion. A corridor with textured walls leads towards a stairway to the rest of the house. The description on the Rightmove website reads: We are pleased to present this fantastic three double-bedroom terraced house to the market with self-contained outbuilding. The property comprises of: three double bedrooms, mid-terrace house with self-contained outbuilding to rear of property with separate access from the street. Comprises of: lounge, sitting room, dining room, open-plan kitchen, downstairs family bathroom with jacuzzi corner bath.  Self-contained outbuilding to rear with access from the back, double glazed  centrally heated , front  rear gardens. Early viewing is highly recommended! story: Man splashed £, on Charizard Pokemon card after lying to get Covid relief loanVinath Oudomsine, from Laurens County, Georgia in the US, admitted in court to having lied to obtain a Covid disaster relief loan then using a large portion of this money to buy a collectable trading card" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Charizard.jpg" width"" "" A man has been sentenced to three years in jail after using Covid- relief money to buy a rare Charizard Pokémon card ByAlice PeacockNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A man has been sentenced to three years in jail after using Covid- relief money to buy a rare Charizard Pokémon card.Vinath Oudomsine, from Laurens County, Georgia in the US, lied to obtain a Covid disaster relief loan then using a large portion of this money to buy a collectable trading card, the court head. According to the Department of Justice for the Southern State of Georgia, Oudomsine was awarded an Economic Injury Disaster Loanfor ,after claiming to own a small business that supported  employees. The loans, which were created as part of Congress’ pandemic relief plan, were intended to be used for businesses to pay workers and rent.  However, once Oudomsine received the money, the Department of Justice said he used ,of it to buy a first-edition, shadowless and holographic Charizard card. The collectable, which had a . gem mint rating, was sold at the PWCC marketplace for that price in late December. “Like moths to the flame, fraudsters like Oudomsine took advantage of these programs to line their own pockets,” said David H. Estes, U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Georgia. Mr Estes said Oudomsine and others like him would be “held accountable” for his greed. U.S. district court judge Dudley H. Bowen has now ordered Oudomsine to pay , , on top of the ,in restitution and three years in prison. Oudomsine had also agreed to turn the Charizard card over to prosecutors. He will have three years of supervised release after the three years in prison. Recently, Iaposve gotten engaged, and weaposve decided to get married in September. story: Im a cleaning expert - getting your house spotless in  minutes can be doneA cleaning expert has explained how you can get your house looking tidy when you dont have much time to spare, offering tips on how to get your home gleaming in just  minutesA cleaning expert has shared some top tipsImage: Getty ImagesByJulia BanimAudience Writer:,  Mar |comments We all want a sparkling home where every object has been put in its correct and proper place, but unfortunately, as is le, things do get busy, and getting really stuck into a good spring clean can feel overwhelming. Thankfully, help is at hand in the form of expert cleaning guru Sarah Dempsey, who swears that you can make your house spotless in just  minutes flat. Sarah - who is employed as a cleaning expert for MyJobQuote - has advised readers to clean little and often to avoid having to spend an entire day doing housework, offering a range of top tips to do just that.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here.Speaking withThe Sun,Sarah suggests starting with the messiest jobs so as to establish priorities, keeping on top of heavy-use areas such as your bathroom and kitchen.According to Sarah, the best way to do this is to make sure to wash up in the evenings, leaving items to drain and air dry, before putting them away in the morning. She explained: This breaks up the task. And it saves you time drying up and reduces the need to keep washing tea towels. Sarah also encouraged people to wipe over their hob after every use, just before it cools down, noting that this preemptive measure makes it much easier to remove food residue.  When it comes to y tasks - like doing the shower and bath - Sarah recommends doing this in two parts to make things easier, taking a few minutes to cover surfaces with a cleaning product, before leaving this on as you go about other tasks or activities. She said: When you come back to it, you should be able to wipe it over with minimal scrubbing and then simply rinse it off. This will take you no longer than ten to fteen minutes of your time. Sarah has also stressed the importance of timing when doing jobs around the house, suggesting doing one bathroom job before hopping in the shower, such as cleaning the toilet or changing the towels. According to Sarah: Doing one thing keeps on top of the cleaning yet only takes a few minutes of your day. With her final tip, Sarah urges readers to clean as you sleep, meaning there are plenty of chores that can be left to sort themselves out once youaposve started them. For example, by putting a cheap, push-on version of a flexible shower attachment on your bath taps, or leaving things to soak overnight while you get some well-deserved rest.Do you have a cleaning-related story to share  We pay for stories. she rolled over for the first time. Just a month later she was sitting up and by the time she was six months, Zoey had taken her first steps - months before babies normally hit the development milestone. Amy, , from Ohio in the US, was completely taken aback and admits she didnapost think it was possible for children to walk so earlier. Her two older children, Ashlyn, , and Lily, four, didnapost take their first steps until after their first birthday. Amy, who works in an escape room, said: “I was so shocked by how quickly Zoey was developing. I didn’t think it was physically possible.“She looked too small to be walking.“She is a little spitfire who is very independent.She will climb and jump on everything.”Amy credits the pandemic lockdowns for Zoey’s ability to start walking at such a young age. She said: “I was unable to work during the lockdown as my workplace was shut so we were at home a lot.“I think Zoey has wanted to chase and play with Lily from the moment she was born. story: Pubs £ roast dinner branded depressive as some say its not even fit for a dogDiners of a Greene King pub in Bristol were left disappointed after ordering a £. roast dinner as what came out was dry and overcooked, and a punter said "I’ve seen better in hospital".The diners expected a proper roast dinner, as was advertised on the menu Image: Greene KingByJohn BettAudience WriterAndy Crick:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A pub has been slammed for a aposdodgyapos roast dinner with dry meat and overcooked veg - and one diner said it was so bad even their dog wouldnapost eat it. The ‘Turkey and Beef Duo Sunday Roast’ was served at the Greene King owned Channings Hotel in Bristol and cost one unlucky diner £..Remaining anonymous, they said that the image on the menu looked great, but the food that was brought out was very disappointing. They got three overdone potatoes, just one piece of caullower cheese, and an odd-shaped chunk of stuffing in a Yorkshire pudding - alongside overcooked meat. What do you think about the roast dinner  Let us know in the comments... A barrister, who uploads to Twitter as WelshGirlAbroad, said that her student daughter was given the depressing looking dish while out with her friends, and she shared a photo of the meal - which was met with dismay - online.She wrote: So this is what Greene King serves by way of award-winning roast dinner at Channings in Bristol. She was with three friends. They didn’t like to complain, thought they’d be assumed to be students trying it on.  They’d had to pay in advance on an app. I’ve seen better in hospital. Soon she was inundated with comments from people who agreed that the food served looked terrible. Linda Caswell wrote: Iaposve just come out of hospital and the food was great. Their chicken dinner knocked this into a cocked hat.” Chris Dale replied: There’s not much our dog would decline to eat, but I think you’ve found it. Mark Savage said: That is not a roast. Fellow barrister Francesca Gardner said: Oh that’s depressing. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Someone  posted: That is dreadful. Another friend asked: What. Is. That  Do they think youcan’t see andhave no appetite  While someone  proclaimed: That is one of the worst meals I have ever seen. Wow. The barrister complained to the pub chain owner but said they needed a week to look into it. She added: They apparently need up to seven days to decide whether it was acceptable to serve this or not. The response had best be worth the wait. The production description for the ‘Turkey and Beef Duo Sunday Roast’ on Greene King’s website reads: “Served with roast potatoes, seasonal vegetables, caullower cheese, sausage meat stuffing, a Yorkshire pudding and rich gravy.” A spokesperson for the Channings Hotel said: Unfortunately the roast dinner served to our customer was not to the usual standard we strive to provide to all of our customers. We are currently looking into what happened to ensure this does not happen again.We have already spoken to our customer directly to apologise and offered to welcome them back for another meal so we can make it up to them. title: archeologists discover worlds first city
story: Archeologists discover worlds ‘first city in old spy satellite imagesExcited anthropologist Dr Jesse Casana feels the breakthrough could unlock some important secrets about Tell Brak, which he claims is around , years older than the Ancient Egyptian pyramidsDr Jesse Casana first saw the worlds ‘first city called Tell Brak in spy satellites Image: Smithsonian Channel WSByCharlie PittockSam Elliott-GibbsReporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments An archeologist who believes he may have discovered the worldaposs ‘first cityapos thanks to incredible images taken by an old spy satellite has spoken of his excitement.The area, claimed to be , years older than the Ancient Egyptian pyramids, is called Tell Brak.Anthropologist Dr Jesse Casana believes the find could be a great breakthrough and may unlock some important information, report Express. The expert has dedicated several years studying the old spy photographs of the Middle East. His work has even featured in documentary ‘The Le of Earth: The Age of Humans’ - and says the snaps from  years ago could hold some very important answers. Dr Casana feels the images are invaluable because the countryside in the Middle East was far less industrialised when they were taken.  He said: “We were able to document something like , previously unknown archaeological sites that, through the history of  years of archaeologists working in the Middle East, no one had ever documented.” Having started as a small settlement in the seventh millennium BC, Tell Brak evolved during the fourth millennium BC into one of the biggest cities in Upper Mesopotamia.That included parts of northwestern Iraq, northeastern Syria and southeastern Turkey. A small settlement first emerged at the site in circa  BC, with pottery found at the site dating back to then. Excavations and surface surveys have revealed that Tell Brak developed as an urban hub slightly before better known cities in southern Mesopotamia such as Uruk.  It grew to around  hectares by the late fth millennium BC, and had more than doubled in size to  hectares in the period spanning  BC to  BC. Tell Brak expanded again around  BC, when it became known as Nagar, and served as the capital of a regional kingdom. For a settlement like Tell Brak to appear as it did, the environment needed to have been transformed by some form of dramatic event. The last ice age ended around , years ago, causing the Earth’s climate to change radically. The planet was at its warmest point in , years. Where Tell Brak lies is an area of the Middle East known as the Fertile Crescent, the culmination of the ice age allowed this area to finally become fertile. Rainfall and temperatures increased, leading to a great expansion of grassland, and climate change fuelled a food revolution.Rainfall and temperatures increased, leading to a great expansion of grassland, and climate change fuelled a food revolution. For millennia, humans had foraged wild grass seeds, but now, wheat and barley proved easy to grow and to control. Ancient humans began to settle and to nurture and protect their crops. These people started to abandon their hunter-gatherer lestyle, instead opting to become farmers. Human reliance on cultivated plants and domesticated animals changed the landscape forever from this point. These settled populations expanded, overwhelming the remaining hunter-gatherers, and transformed the landscape with their fields, villages, towns and eventually cities. A ‘tell’, in Middle Eastern archaeology, is a raised mound marking the site of an ancient city. In ancient times, houses were built from mud, which would crumble easily when exposed to the elements. Earlier debris would be levelled off in the rebuilding process and new buildings would be erected on top, so most tells are typically shaped like a low truncated cone. At over  metres high, and  by  metres in area, Tell Brak — or Nagar as it was then — is one of the largest in the area. It is believed to have thrived under dferent peoples right up until circa  BC when it was destroyed by the Assyrians. story: "Im a crazy girl!" Image: YouTubeByJoe Smith:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA family have put a microphone on their three-year-old daughter to capture her hilarious commentary as she skis.Toddler Adia Leidums can be heard singing little songs to herself as she skis through thick woodland. Three-year-old Adia speeds down mountains on her tiny toddler skis in Fernie, British Columbia.Her parents Erich and Courtney say theyaposre teaching her to ski at a young age in order to build her confidence and resiliency.Adia’s parents, Erich Leidums and Courtney Haeusler decided to mic-up little Adia as she honed her skiing skills into on the slopes at Fernie Alpine Resort and after uploading her skiing videos to YouTube, her pep-talks are now world famous.“I got the idea a couple of years back from a hockey dad that mic’d up his son at a practice to catch his narration and self-monologue,” said Erich, who said Adia’s self-talk was well worth capturing. “We would hear those things before we mic’d her up, she would say those things. “When I was using my go-pro without the mic, I would try to get closer to her, and after she fell and got up sheaposd have something to say to the camera but I always had to get really close.“With a microphone it doesn’t miss anything she says. Any sigh, laugh or giggle- it’s pretty adorable,” he told theTerrace Standard . Erich’s of his daughter’s cute downhill antics have racked up millions of views over on his YouTube channel. Adia is the youngest of Erich and Courtney’s three children, along with Lucaand August , who’ve all been skiing for around  months.They’re all accomplished skiers, and feature heavily in Erich’s videos of skiing Fernie Alpine Resort as part of his ‘That Mountain Le’ videos on YouTube and Instagram.The couple have said they aim to be anti-helicopter parents and placed their children on skis at a very young age. “Our goal is to raise confident, caring children who are self-aware and I think that comes with taking risks,” Courtney said. title: little girl beautiful voice made
story: Little girl with beautul voice made the world weep for children of UkraineThere has never been a more powerful version of Let It Go, Polly Hudson says of the footage from an underground bunker, reminding us how lives have been turned upside down for millions of innocentsAmelia singing in the bunker Image: PAopinionByPolly Hudson:,  Mar |commentsIt’s the chaos surrounding her that you notice first. The ­desperate families squeezed in, standing, sitting, lying wherever they can, next to their precariously piled ­belongings, packed into the dank underground space they now call home. There’s an air of restlessness, a palpable sense of tension and anxiety. How could there not be And then, completely unexpectedly, something magical happens. Little Amelia – age unknown, but probably, what, seven or eight  – stands up on a chair. She’s wearing a sparkly jumper with stars on it, from HM a few years ago – my friend’s daughter has the same one and still loves it too. Hands clenched together shyly, unbrushed hair pulled back into a ponytail, Amelia plucks up all her courage, opens her mouth and starts to sing Let It Go, from Frozen. And like a spell cast in the movie her song comes from, the Kyiv shelter falls silent. Everyone turns and gives this small blonde scrap of a girl their mesmerised full attention. No one moves. Babies stop crying. This captive audience cannot take their eyes off her, as they listen to her sweet, steady voice, a chink of shining light in the unimaginable ­darkness of Ukraine.She has given these people the gt of focusing on something other than the living nightmare they’re enduring, albeit briefly, and there isn’t a dry eye in the room. Or from any of the millions around the globe who have since watched the video on social media.Despite probably never having heard Ukrainian before, the song is in the universal language of Disney, kids from any country in the world watching it could name that tune in three. In the caption, the woman who posted it explains that Amelia told her she wanted to be “a singer on a grand stage” – an ambition now fulfilled, just not in a way anyone would want. Their poor parents can, at least, try to fight back, but the children of Ukraine are utterly defenceless in this war. Putin is torturing and traumatising these pure, faultless human beings, turning them into orphans. Murdering  of them.  Amelia and the other kids in that shelter, and similar ones across the country. Danya and Mpak, the boys trapped in Calais, denied entry by our callous government because they don’t have the right paperwork. The -year-old who braved a -mile journey to safety alone. Heroic President Volodymyr Zelensky’ s own children – Aleksandra, , and Kiril, age nine – who have targets on their backs. Polina, the girl with the pink hair, and her brother Semyon, both dead. And the many other nameless young casualties.All entirely blameless, innocent children – just like their entirely blameless, innocent mums and dads – frightened for their lives.  Two weeks ago they were moaning about homework, playing with their friends, not eating their vegetables. Now, suddenly plunged into a reality where growing up without their fathers may well be the best case scenario. The least worst of their horrendous options. When Let It Go lyricist Kristen Anderson-Lopez saw Amelia’s rendition, she tweeted: “Dear Little Girl with the beautul voice, my husband and I wrote this song. The way you sing it is like a magic trick that spreads the light in your heart and heals everyone who hears it.” She finished by urging Amelia to “Keep singing!” If only that choice was hers. title: north korea terrified russian invasion
story: North Korea terried of Russian invasion and will never give up nuclear weaponsA North Korean official has claimed Ukraine would have never been invadedit had kept its stash of Soviet nuclear weapons - and another said only nukes could prevent foreign invasionsOne North Korean official said only nukes could prevent foreign invasions Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByMirror:,  Mar |commentsNuclear weapons are the only thing saving North Korea from sharing Ukraineaposs fate, party officials believe, in the first sign that even Pyongyang is nervous about Russiaaposs invasion.One high-ranking North Korean official said Ukraine would never have been attackedit had kept its cache of Soviet nuclear weapons.While another said only nukes could prevent foreign invasions, and that the regime should prioritise national defence above seeking international aid. The startling admissions were revealed by Daily NK, a newspaper with sources inside the country, based in neighbouring South Korea. Want all the latest news and analysis from Ukraine to our World News Bulletin here  Since Russiaaposs invasion of Ukraine, more and more party cadres in North Korea say Pyongyang can never abandon its nuclear weapons, the paper reported. North Korea is apparently growing more attached to its nuclear arsenal since the crisis in Ukraine.The consensus among high-ranking North Korean cadres is that the Ukraine crisis began when Kyiv abandoned its nuclear arsenal. Follow all todayaposs latest updates on the conflict with our live blog After the fall of the USSR in , Ukraine held about a third of the Soviet nuclear arsenal, but it gave the weapons up in  in exchange for security guarantees from Russia, Britain and the UK.It comes as satellite images showed new activity at North Koreaaposs Punggye-ri nuclear testing site, which was last used for a detonation in  before it was officially shuttered in . The International Atomic Energy Agencyalso reported on Monday that there was building work at the Yongbyon nuclear power plant, which produces material for nuclear weapons.  For Lee Yang-goo, the former South Korean ambassador to Ukraine, Russiaaposs invasion deals a fatal blow to any prospect of denuclearisation. Speaking to NK News, a specialist publication focusing on the secretive state, he said: North Korea already did not have much willingness to denuclearise. But looking at the graphic scenes coming out of Ukraine, Pyongyang will further solidy their internal and external justication for possessing nuclear weapons. Now, after this crisis, it will be dficult for any country to make a denuclearisation pitch to North Korea.  North Koreans think that nuclear weapons are the absolute saviour of the country. The signs of unease among the North Korean elite appear at odds with the countryaposs official position on the conflict in Ukraine - which is that the US is to blame. In a UN vote on March , North Korea was one of only four countries to vote against a resolution condemning the invasion. Chris Ogden, a senior lecturer in the School of International Relations at the University of St Andrews, said Pyongyangaposs position was more about mollying Russia than condemning Ukraine. I am not surePyongyang has any reason to openly scorn Ukraine, he said. I think that these statements are more about maintaining some linkages with Moscow and doing its best to maintain these relations. In this sense, Ukraine could be any other country in the region. What matters more to North Korea is to support Russia and to couch this support in terms of ongoing western imperialism as a threat to Russiaaposs national sovereignty - which Pyongyang also fears. The example of Ukraine is not the only reason North Korea fears giving up its nukes. Pyongyang already viewed the denuclearisation of Libya in  as a cautionary tale, noting how NATO later intervened there in , leading to the death of its leader, Muammar Gaddafi. story: Putins strict daily routine includes hours of swimming, late nights, and no alcoholA mass exodus of Ukrainians have left their country, after President Putin shattered peace in Europe, with Russian forces attacking big cities and the homes of everyday citizensPutin has frequently posed while bare chested Image: SPUTNIK AFP via Getty ImagesByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsVladimir Putin has launched a devastating attack on Ukraine, with missiles launched on its cities while soldiers attempt to close in on the capital of Kyiv.He seeks to take control of the neighbouring country and overthrow its democratically elected government.Yesterday, Defence Secretary Ben Wallace said the Russian President is a spent force and this war will spell the end of the world leader.The odd, reclusive President has a history of macho photo ops - designed to promote himself as an action hero - and an intense daily schedule - The former KGB man doesnapost wake up until mid-morning and has his breakfast around noon before starting his punishing exercise schedule. Author Ben Judah profiled Putin in  for his book Fragile Empire: How Russia Fell in and Out of Love with Vladimir Putin. Follow all todayaposs latest updates on the conflict with our live blog He normally begins his day with a large omelette or bowl of porridge - with some cottage cheese and quail eggs on the side. After this, author Steven Lee Myers claims that the Russian president drinks a juice containing beetroot and horseradish. The organic ingredients are sourced from the farmland estates of the Patriarch Kirill, Russiaaposs religious leader.He then has a post-meal coffee before swimming for two hours, with author Judah claiming he gets much of Russia’s thinking done, during this time.  He then finishes his workout with some weight-lting - with the leader keen to emulate a macho image to the public, while rolling news plays on the TV. During this time, he is mostly alone, author Steve Myers claims, writing: His closest companion seemed to be his black Labrador, Koni, who waited poolside as he completed his laps.Itaposs early afternoon when Putin reportedly turns his attention to his daily briefings - which includes articles from Russian and international media, as well as domestic and foreign affairs.  Judah wrote: He is obsessed with information. The thickest, fattest folders at his request are not intelligence reports: they are press clippings. His hands first open the Russian press digest. The most important papers come at the front: the obsequious national tabloids. These matter most, with their millions of readers. But it was reported in  that he tries to avoid computers, in favour of paper documents and a telephone. And he reportedly rarely uses the internet, although his advisers may show him a satirical video mocking him from time-to-time. After his late start, heaposs reportedly a night owl and stays up into the early hours working. And at weekends, he keeps busy, with studies, although he also tries to play as much ice hockey as possible. He also keeps a strict schedule abroad - with everything he uses, such as toiletries and bedsheets, replaced over security fears.And he will never accept food that hasnapost been tested first and avoids drinking alcohol, Politico reports, except during formal receptions.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Vladimir Putin" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
